newsitem.title: ISRAEL: Highlights of Netanyahu's first 100 days.
newsitem.headline: Highlights of Netanyahu's first 100 days.

text.p: Benjamin Netanyahu became Israel's prime minister 100 days ago on Thursday. Here are some highlights of his time in office:

June 18 - Netanyahu, the right-wing Likud leader who ousted Labour party Prime Minister Shimon Peres in May elections, takes office promising to promote peace with Israel's Arab neighbours while ensuring security.
June 28 - Netanyahu sends two representatives to meet Palestinian President Yasser Arafat in what senior PLO offical calls "first official contact" with new Israeli government.
July 7 - Netanyahu's government, which inherited a bloated public sector from the Labour government, approves steep cut in 1997 spending. Cuts still need parliamentary approval.
July 23 - Arafat meets Israeli Foreign Minister David Levy in Gaza in first high-level meeting since Netanyahu took office.
Aug 2 - Netanyahu infuriates Palestinians by lifting a four-year freeze on Jewish settlement expansion in occupied West Bank imposed by the previous government.
Aug 9 - Israel says no progress on peace moves until Palestinian Authority shuts offices in Arab East Jerusalem.
Aug 11 - Arafat threatens Israel with international arbitration if his peace goals are frustrated.
Aug 22 - Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak warns could cancel Middle East economic conference in November if Israel stalls on peace.
Aug 25 - Bowing to Israeli demands, Arafat's Palestinian Authority shuts two East Jerusalem offices.
Aug 27 - Israel hoists bulldozer over Jerusalem's Old City wall to demolish Palestinian community centre it said was built without permit.
Aug 28 - Arafat says Israel declared war on Palestinians with settlement expansion.

Aug 29 - Palestinians hold first general strike in West Bank and Gaza in two years to protest at Israeli policy; Heads of Israeli-PLO steering committee on implemention of interim peace deals hold first meeting since Netanyahu took office.
Sept 1 - Israeli and PLO negotiators launch marathon talks with Norwegian mediation aimed at Netanyahu-Arafat meeting.
Sept 4 - Netanyahu and Arafat hold first summit, at Erez crossing between Israel and Gaza.

Sept 17 - Government-appointed committee proposes sweeping reform in Israel's capital markets. Netanyahu, faced with plunging stock and bond prices, had taken office promising to reform Israel's markets.

Sept 24 - Israeli government opens tourist tunnel near Islamic holy site, igniting protests reminiscent of 6-1/2-year Palestinian uprising and further souring relations with Arab states. Israeli government demands Egypt stop "threatening" it for taking slower approach to peace than its Labour-led predecessor.
